question.text: Vasco da Gama was the first European to reach India by sea in 1498.

questions.explanation: Vasco da Gama, a Portuguese explorer, reached Calicut in 1498, opening the sea route to India.

question.text: The British East India Company was established in 1600.

questions.explanation: The British East India Company was granted a royal charter by Queen Elizabeth I in 1600.

question.text: Francisco de Almeida introduced the 'Blue Water Policy' to strengthen Portuguese naval dominance.

questions.explanation: Francisco de Almeida, the first Portuguese Governor of India, introduced the 'Blue Water Policy' to dominate the Indian Ocean.

question.text: The Dutch East India Company was established before the British East India Company.

questions.explanation: The Dutch East India Company (VOC) was established in 1602, two years after the British East India Company.

question.text: The Battle of Plassey in 1757 marked the beginning of British political dominance in India.

questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey established British control over Bengal and paved the way for British expansion in India.

question.text: The Portuguese were the first Europeans to establish trading posts in India.

questions.explanation: The Portuguese, led by Vasco da Gama, were the first Europeans to establish trading posts in India in the early 1500s.

question.text: Robert Clive led the British forces during the Battle of Buxar in 1764.

questions.explanation: Robert Clive led British forces to victory at the Battle of Buxar, securing British dominance over Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.

question.text: The Treaty of Paris in 1763 ended the First Carnatic War between the British and the French.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle in 1748 ended the First Carnatic War, while the Treaty of Paris ended the Seven Years' War.

question.text: The French established their first trading post in Chandernagore.

questions.explanation: The French established their first trading post in Chandernagore, West Bengal, in 1673.

question.text: The Dutch were driven out of India by the British after the Battle of Wandiwash in 1760.

questions.explanation: The French, not the Dutch, were defeated by the British at the Battle of Wandiwash, ending French ambitions in India.

question.text: The Portuguese established their first fort in India at Goa.

questions.explanation: The Portuguese established their first fort at Cochin in 1503. Goa was captured later in 1510.

question.text: Alfonso de Albuquerque was responsible for capturing Goa for the Portuguese.

questions.explanation: Alfonso de Albuquerque captured Goa from the Bijapur Sultanate in 1510, establishing it as a Portuguese colony.

question.text: The British shifted their headquarters from Surat to Bombay in 1687.

questions.explanation: The British shifted their headquarters from Surat to Bombay in 1687 after receiving the territory from the Portuguese.

question.text: The French Governor Dupleix successfully defeated the British in the Third Carnatic War.

questions.explanation: The French Governor Dupleix was defeated in the Third Carnatic War by the British forces led by Robert Clive and Eyre Coote.

question.text: The Battle of Buxar took place in 1757.

questions.explanation: The Battle of Buxar took place in 1764, seven years after the Battle of Plassey.

question.text: The Dutch established their headquarters in India at Pulicat.

questions.explanation: The Dutch established Pulicat as their headquarters in 1610, before moving to Nagapattinam.

question.text: The Treaty of Bassein (1802) was signed between the British and the Marathas.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Bassein was signed between the British and Peshwa Baji Rao II, which increased British influence over the Marathas.

question.text: The British East India Company was granted Diwani rights over Bengal after the Battle of Buxar.

questions.explanation: The British East India Company was granted Diwani rights in 1765, allowing them to collect revenue in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.

question.text: The French East India Company was founded in 1664.

questions.explanation: The French East India Company was established by Colbert under the reign of King Louis XIV in 1664.

question.text: The first British factory in India was established at Surat.

questions.explanation: The British East India Company established its first factory at Surat in 1613 after obtaining permission from Mughal Emperor Jahangir.

question.text: Pondicherry was the first French settlement in India.

questions.explanation: Pondicherry (Puducherry) became the first major French settlement in India in 1674.

question.text: The British captured Madras from the Portuguese in 1639.

questions.explanation: The British acquired Madras from the local ruler of Chandragiri in 1639, not from the Portuguese.

question.text: The Portuguese were the last European power to leave India.

questions.explanation: The Portuguese left India in 1961 after Goa was annexed by India. The French retained Pondicherry until 1954.

question.text: The Danes established settlements in Tranquebar and Serampore.

questions.explanation: The Danish East India Company established trading posts in Tranquebar (Tamil Nadu) and Serampore (West Bengal).

question.text: The Dutch primarily focused on the spice trade in the Malabar Coast and Ceylon.

questions.explanation: The Dutch East India Company concentrated on the spice trade and established control over Ceylon and the Malabar Coast.

question.text: Fort St. George was built by the British in Bombay.

questions.explanation: Fort St. George was built by the British in Madras (Chennai) in 1644, not Bombay.

question.text: The First Carnatic War ended with the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle.

questions.explanation: The First Carnatic War ended in 1748 with the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle, which restored Madras to the British.

question.text: The French Governor Dupleix was instrumental in the Second Carnatic War.

questions.explanation: Joseph Fran√ßois Dupleix, the French Governor-General, played a key role in the Second Carnatic War.

question.text: The British East India Company lost the Battle of Wandiwash in 1760.

questions.explanation: The British defeated the French at the Battle of Wandiwash in 1760, marking the end of French power in India.

question.text: The Dutch lost their influence in India after the Battle of Colachel.

questions.explanation: The Dutch were defeated by the Kingdom of Travancore at the Battle of Colachel in 1741, leading to the decline of Dutch influence in India.

question.text: The Treaty of Seringapatam ended the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Seringapatam ended the Third Anglo-Mysore War in 1792. The Fourth war ended with the death of Tipu Sultan in 1799.

question.text: The Portuguese were the first Europeans to introduce printing technology in India.

questions.explanation: The Portuguese introduced the first printing press in Goa in 1556.

question.text: The Battle of Swally was fought between the Portuguese and the British.

questions.explanation: The Battle of Swally (1612) marked a decisive victory for the British East India Company over the Portuguese, strengthening British influence.

question.text: The French were the last European power to establish trading posts in India.

questions.explanation: The Danes (Danish) were the last European power to establish trading posts in India.

question.text: The first English factory in India was established during the reign of Mughal Emperor Akbar.

questions.explanation: The first English factory was established at Surat during the reign of Emperor Jahangir in 1613.

question.text: The Marathas allied with the British during the Second Anglo-Mysore War.

questions.explanation: The Marathas and the Nizam of Hyderabad allied with the British during the Second Anglo-Mysore War against Tipu Sultan.

question.text: The Dutch established Fort St. Angelo in Kerala.

questions.explanation: The Dutch captured Fort St. Angelo in Kannur (Kerala) from the Portuguese in 1663.

question.text: The Treaty of Paris (1763) ended the conflict between the British and the Dutch in India.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Paris (1763) ended hostilities between the British and the French, not the Dutch.

question.text: The French established the city of Chandernagore as their major trading center in Bengal.

questions.explanation: Chandernagore was established by the French as a key trading post in Bengal.

question.text: The British acquired Bombay from the Dutch through the Treaty of Westminster.

questions.explanation: The British acquired Bombay from the Portuguese as part of the dowry of Catherine of Braganza in 1661.

question.text: The Battle of Chinsurah in 1759 marked the defeat of the Dutch by the British.

questions.explanation: The British defeated the Dutch at the Battle of Chinsurah in Bengal, further consolidating British power in India.

question.text: The French Governor Dupleix attempted to establish French supremacy in South India through alliances with Indian rulers.

questions.explanation: Dupleix aimed to expand French influence by forming alliances with Indian rulers during the Carnatic Wars.

question.text: The British initially focused their trade in the Malabar region.

questions.explanation: The British initially focused their trade in Surat, Gujarat, before expanding to the eastern and southern coasts.

question.text: The Portuguese were defeated by the Mughals at the Battle of Hooghly in 1632.

questions.explanation: The Mughal forces, led by Shah Jahan, defeated the Portuguese at Hooghly in 1632.

question.text: The Treaty of Madras ended the Second Carnatic War.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Madras ended the First Anglo-Mysore War in 1769, not the Carnatic War.

question.text: The Dutch ceded Nagapattinam to the British after the Fourth Anglo-Dutch War.

questions.explanation: The Dutch ceded Nagapattinam to the British following their defeat in the Fourth Anglo-Dutch War (1780-1784).

question.text: The Portuguese established their first settlement at Diu in India.

questions.explanation: The Portuguese established their first settlement at Cochin in 1503, while Diu was captured later.

question.text: The First Anglo-Maratha War ended with the Treaty of Salbai in 1782.

questions.explanation: The Treaty of Salbai (1782) ended the First Anglo-Maratha War, establishing peace between the British and the Marathas.

question.text: The French lost control of Pondicherry in 1761 but regained it through the Treaty of Paris.

questions.explanation: Pondicherry was returned to the French by the British under the Treaty of Paris in 1763.

question.text: The British Parliament passed the Regulating Act in 1773 to oversee the administration of the East India Company.

questions.explanation: The Regulating Act of 1773 marked the first step towards British parliamentary control over the East India Company.

question.text: The Battle of Plassey was fought between the British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal.

questions.explanation: The Battle of Plassey was fought between the British East India Company and the Nawab of Bengal on June 23, 1757.
